The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization, presented its third annual America's Corporate Conscience Awards last night to five corporations that it regards as exemplifying corporate social responsibility. Two other companies received honorable mention.

The council, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary, publishes consumer guidebooks and studies on topics related to corporate performance. In December it published ''Shopping for a Better World: A Quick and Easy Guide to Socially Responsible Supermarket Shopping,'' which evaluates 138 companies that produce supermarket goods.
It has also conducted studies on nuclear disarmament, verification of arms control agreements and toxic waste disposal.

The awards were announced at a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel: Charitable Giving: Dayton Hudson Corporation. The Minneapolis-based retail chain has donated money to numerous programs for economic and social development, including a 24-hour telephone hot line for family problems in Iowa, day care centers in Arizona and California, and a conference in San Francisco on AIDS in the workplace. Community Action: Digital Equipment Corporation. Based in Maynard, Mass., this computer company has many job-training programs, makes substantial purchases from businesses owned by women and members of minority groups, and sponsors educational programs for low-income students. Employer Responsiveness: Federal Express Corporation. The company, based in Memphis, has a no lay-off policy and offers cash awards, free dinners and other rewards and incentives to employees. Environmental Responsibility: Applied Energy Services Inc. An independent power generator and energy consultant based in Arlington, Va., the company has developed techniques to minimize pollution from its new coal-burning plant in Connecticut. It has also donated $2 million for the planting of 52 million trees in Guatemala to help combat the global warming trend. Equal Opportunity: Eastman Kodak Company. Based in Rochester, the company does one-fourth of its purchasing from small businesses owned by women, and it helped found the Rochester Business Opportunity Corporation, which helps minority-owned businesses. Honorable Mention: H. B. Fuller Company, a Minneapolis-based company that makes paints, adhesives and sealants, honored for its environmental record, and Newman's Own Inc., a food company founded by the actor Paul Newman, honored for donating profits to charity.
